keyTakeAways: Acetaminophen (Tylenol) is one of the most studied medications in history, with no clear scientific evidence linking it to autism or ADHD in children during pregnancy.
The FDA has not found clear evidence that appropriate use of acetaminophen during pregnancy causes adverse neurodevelopmental outcomes.
A large 2024 study involving over 2 million children found no significant association between acetaminophen use and autism, ADHD, or intellectual disability.
A 2024 analysis of 46 studies found only a weak or associative link between acetaminophen use and autism, not causation.
The American College of Obstetricians & Gynecologists states that no reputable study has shown a causal relationship between acetaminophen and neurodevelopmental disorders.
The Trump administration’s claim that Tylenol causes autism was unsupported by evidence and contradicted by major medical organizations.
Kenvue, the maker of Tylenol, has formally opposed a proposed FDA label change, arguing it lacks scientific basis and would be arbitrary.
The FDA has not updated its official website on acetaminophen since August 2024, maintaining that no clear risk has been established.
Regulatory agencies in the European Union, United Kingdom, and Health Canada confirm that acetaminophen use during pregnancy remains safe.
The Informed Consent Action Network filed a citizen’s petition with the FDA to add warnings about autism risk, but it has been challenged by Kenvue as unsupported.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Kenvue, the maker of Tylenol, has challenged a proposed FDA labeling change that would warn about a possible link between acetaminophen use during pregnancy and autism or ADHD in children. Despite claims by former President Donald Trump and HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that Tylenol increases neurodevelopmental risks, scientific evidence—including a large 2024 study of over 2 million children and expert reviews—shows no clear causal link. The FDA maintains that no clear evidence exists of harm from appropriate acetaminophen use, and regulatory bodies in the EU, UK, and Canada confirm its safety. Kenvue argues that the proposed label changes are unsupported by science and would mislead the public. The controversy highlights tensions between political messaging and medical evidence in public health policy.
title: Tylenol’s maker pushes back against possible label change linking pain reliever’s use in pregnancy to autism
